description.text:
A stand to hold the RSA SecurID at a better angle, so the number is easier to read.  
I saw kazsoft's stand and realized how useful it would be, but I wanted something lower and harder to knock over.  I made mine just high enough to be seen over the back of my keyboard.  When nudged it slide rather than tips.  
The "waist" in the design allows you to pick it up off the stand easily.  
The model has a brim to help it stick to the print bed, and the bottom edge is turned under at 45 deg to give it a clean-looking bottom edge after you trim off the brim.

2 shells
.2mm layer height
10% infill
No rafts
No support

title: Eclipse Clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is my Eclipse Clock body. Link to video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j0Z_QiA_onI There are a whole lot of other parts and processes required, but this is the key to it all... Plus it is a BIG introduction to Charlieplexing LEDs.

This Eclipse Clock is an awesome Thing. It is designed to take sixty 3mm LEDs, inserted outward through the holes.
Wire them up with either:
five WS2803 chips, or
a Charlieplexing network. Add in an Arduino or clone, a Real-Time Clock module, and attach it to a slab of wood, colored plexi, or some other solid object. Attached are:
The Eclipse Clock body,
a Charlieplex network diagram Charlieplexing is a very interesting concept, designed to run many LEDs on just a few Arduino pins base on the formula: #LEDs = #pins (#pins-1) (in this case, I needed 60 LEDs, 72 = 9 8 - I had to do 9 pins, because 8 pins would only run 56 LEDs). Unfortunately, I can not provide the code for this, as some of my code is proprietary for other patent-pending products I am working on. To get a basic version of this running really isn't much more than 200 lines of code, including visual alert routines, a time-set mode, and interfacing with a Clock module. I am selling arduino clones, pre-programmed, with instructions on how to assemble, as well as full kits, including LED's, clock module, Arduino clone, wire, and a rotary encoder. Just PM me. Not only will this be the coolest clock around, but if you use a Chronodot real-time clock module, it'll also be the most accurate. Edit: I uploaded a video of this clock in action. Enjoy! Update: Redesigned with OpenSCAD. The fins print properly now.
I also make a back cover/Hole template. This cover offers room for an small arduino/clone (pro-mini, etc), and holes for marking/drilling as well as installing a power plug and Rotary Encoder.

author: caseythehost

description.text:
This is my cnc machine's 3d model and various parts to make it. These are the same parts as Ive been releasing little by little over the last month or two. As I build everything and measure everything out, Ill add the measurements, and pictures.  
EDIT: Dont try printing CNC Model.stl, it's too big for your printer. :P It's just there to show what the cnc would look like after completed. I know it doesnt have the parts above added into the file, it's just a rough doodle that serves it's purpose just to see what the full cnc looks like.

So far, this is the dimensions of stuff that Ive designed so far. Im using 2x4 pieces of lumber cut down to size, and z carriage piece is made of 1x4 pieces. The rotary tool is just a simple dremel clone from harbor freight, it runs off of 12v. For the 7/16 bearings, I printed 6 of them, 3 for each side for maximum stability on the rods, bearing holders, I printed 4 for each of the x and z axis, so each will have 4, along with two of the nut trap files (the small anti-backlash nut design), it's all designed to fit together and come out flat with equal spacing. The x end pieces, I printed 4 times, one for top/bottom of both x and z axis. It also needs 4 of the 7/16 rod holders, one for each end of the two rods. Im just using 5/16in threaded rod atm, but you can substitute it for 1/4 acme rod since I heard that the nut size is the same. Smooth rods: 7/16 - x axis - 32 1/16in 814.4mm
8mm - y axis - 15 3/4in 400mm
8mm - z axis - 6in 152.4mm Cutting area: 15x15x3/4in 380x380x38.1mm lumber pieces - 2x4 base end - 15 3/4in 400mm
base sides - 30 9/16in 776.3mm
y/z support sides - 15 3/4 400mm lumber pieces - 1x4 Will add this in later.

description.text: This little bracket provides an easy way to mount a PCB vertically. It includes a small wire clamp that can be used to hold PCB wires in place. I use it to hold a small 1" x 0.5" PCB that has a bank of header pins for X, Y, Z, and E motors. (See photo.)

Set User-defined values, render, and print. Insert the PCB in the channel and route the wires between the mounting holes. Place the wire clamp on top and mount using the holes. You may need to tweak the values a bit for a snug fit.

title: World's Lightest Propeller Guards for Estes ProtoX Proto X Quadcopter

description.text: This "Thing" is a set of 4 super-lightweight propeller guards for your Estes ProtoX quadcopter. I believe they are the lightest prop guards in the world...at least right now. I designed them in Autodesk Inventor, and printed them out using MakerWare. The most popular prop guard on Thingiverse currently based on download count is the "Proto X Rotor Saver" bylazlowcv (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:244019). It is a GREAT prop guard, but it weighs nearly 2 grams including the guard and the clip, plus you have to glue the guard and the clip together before you can use it. The set of 4 guards in this "Thing" weighs a total of only 0.92 grams, which is less than half the weight of the other guard...and more than a full gram lighter! These guards simply press-fit down over each motor mount and protect the prop in the event of crashes. Note that there are two "left" and two "right" guards based on the orientation of each motor mount. After you print them out, make sure you are putting the correct guard on each motor mount. Each guard only will fit on two of the motor mounts. I printed mine out on a Replicator 1 using black PET filament from our friends at MadeSolid. PET works really great on the MakerBot and I use it a lot instead of ABS. I printed these at 250c head temperature and 60c heated bed temperature. However, I'm certain these would work fine if printed in ABS or PLA. I printed a set of these guards for my youngest son (he is 13), and he had an issue where in a very hard crash, the guard turned the motor mount a little bit. Watch out for this issue...in his case it turned the motor far enough to dislodge the power wire. My son was easily able to re-solder the wire, so he was back flying in a few minutes. I have crashed mine very hard many times and have not had this happen to my quad. If you look at the photos, you might notice a few mods I have made to my ProtoX quadcopter. They are as follows: 1.) Remove the body shell: This will save you about 0.54 grams of weight, and the shell really is only cosmetic. 2.) Stick the battery on the bottom: You can just pull the battery off using the adhesive, and stick it right to the bottom in the very center of the circuit board. Route the wire around the charging connector, and you are all set. This will improve the stability greatly because the battery provides more of a pendulum effect and makes the quad less top-heavy. 3.) Print out the controller stick extensions from our friends at Local Motors (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243859) and install them: This will make your controller much more stable! Enjoy!

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

These are some spacers which can be placed in between a swivel chair base and the wheels to raise the swivel chair about 2cm higher than it originally was.
I designed this little piece because we (HackerspaceSG) recently got a chair in which the middle cylinder had sunken through the base and started hitting the ground, destabilizing the chair and damaging the carpet.
The sources are kept up to date in Github: https://github.com/hyperair/chair-wheel-adapter

• Print the two parts (body and legs) separately, in the orientation provided. This is necessary to increase the part strength as 3d-printed parts have very poor shear strength along the Z-axis.
  • Hammer the legs into the body (the round, untoothed edge goes into the circular groove in the body.
  • Remove a wheel from the chair.
  • Hammer the part into the chair (toothed legs go into the part where the wheel was.
  • Hammer the wheel into the part.
  • Repeat for the other 4 legs.

This is a ball bearing spool holder that mounts on two pegboard hooks to hold the spool above your printer.  
To assemble it, you'll need two 608 bearings, a length of 5/16" threaded rod and two nuts.  Make sure the washers are mounted with their shoulders facing inward, toward the bearings, to make sure the bearings can spin freely.  
You will need to print two hanger blocks, two outside spacers, two washers and one spacer to make a spool holder wide enough for a (MakerFarm) 1Kg filament spool.  
The holder mounts on two long pegboard hooks, 4" apart.

title: New Thick Sheet for RepRap Mendel

description.text: These are my new thick sheet parts for RepRap Mendel. I was inspired by the mounting plate for the TechZone boards (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2174). I used a modified version of this for my mother board and extruder. And then made a board for my steppers. I have also included my modified froglet that is simpler for cutting out with saws. Be sure to check out pictures and more information about my Mendel @ reprapbreeding.blogspot.com/

Cut out per full sized PDFs and attach to Mendel.  You only use the y-bar-clamps and circuit-board-spacers (you will need 4 of each). You do not use the "circuit-board-bracket-m3_4off.stl" with this design.  I also just cut my build plate square (eliminating the nozzle clearing area).

description.text:
A model of the SpaceX Dragon spacecraft V1. The model depicts the variant that is used for NASA's Commercial Resupply Services program. This model is drawn in inches to true size, this was done to make it easier to change and keep track of its scale.
Certain aspects of the model were drawn inaccurate on purpose because to draw them realistically would cause problems during printing (Ex:solar array thickness, trunk thickness, trunk depth, alignment guides on the Common Berthing Mechanism...).
I created this model because I wanted something more accurate than the model already on Thingiverse. Note: If you use this model then remember the license requires you to attribute. Please let me know if there are any issues with the models. Files:
---------------------
Model description: Basic capsule shape with no detail.
  • Dragon capsule simple.stl
    Model description: Heavily detailed capsule.
  • Dragon capsule complex.stl
    Model description: Capsule, trunk and solar arrays are one piece. Capsule has no detail.
  • Dragon spacecraft joined simple.stl
    Model description: Capsule, trunk and solar arrays are one piece. Capsule is heavily detailed.
  • Dragon spacecraft joined complex.stl
    Model description: Model is meant to be displayed on a flat surface and is intended to be assembled without glue. The trunk is removable and the solar arrays can be rotated a full 360 degrees. The capsule is heavily detailed and has four holes on the bottom of it to help keep it attached to the trunk. Trunk depth is limited to avoid conflicting with how the solar arrays are attached. This is the version seen in the main image.
  • Dragon spacecraft exploded Capsule.stl
  • Dragon spacecraft exploded Trunk.stl
  • Dragon spacecraft exploded Solar array.stl
  • Dragon spacecraft exploded.stl
  • Dragon spacecraft exploded.dwg
    File description: AutoCad source file.
  • Dragon spacecraft.dwg
    File description: The Dragon spacecraft files that were on Thingiverse from 8 Juanuary 2013 to 8 July 2013.
  • Old Dragon spacecraft models.zip
    • Common spacecraft model scales:
    ---------------------
    1:144
  • Dragon_spacecraft_joined.stl = 1.8 inches (46 mm) tall and 4.8 inches (122 mm) wide.
    1:72
  • Dragon_spacecraft_joined.stl = 3.5 inches (89 mm) tall and 9.6 inches (243 mm) wide.
  • Dragon capsule = 2.0 inches (51 mm) tall and 2.1 inches (53 mm) wide.
    1:48
  • Dragon capsule = 3.1 inches (79 mm) tall and 3.2 inches (81 mm) wide.
  • Dragon_spacecraft_exploded__Solar_array.stl = 6.7 inches (170 mm) wide.
    1:24
  • Dragon capsule = 6.1 inches (155 mm) tall and 6.3 iches (160 mm) wide.
  • Dragon_spacecraft_exploded__Solar_array.stl = 13.4 inches (340 mm) wide.

comments.text:
Great capsule. I have been wanting a Dragon for some time. How did you make it so detailed?
I printed in roughly 1:48 scale. First I sliced it into 3 pieces so I could print all with out supports or rafts. Sliced off heat shield just below main hatch, as indicated by photos of Dragon in orbit. Also sliced off the top with the docking ring just where the main side wall steps. Printed central section in white with 0% infill. Printed top in white with 20% infill. Flipped heat shield and printed flat side down in gray with 20% infill. All with 4 shells and 0.075mm layer height. Came out beautiful.
Any chance you could do the trunk with the same level of detail?
BTW, you cam make he solar panels much thinner, like 2mm, and it prints fine standing on the long edge.
comments.author: bdipaolo

comments.text:
"How did you make it so detailed?"
Lots and lots of work. I used the DragonLab dimensions posted on SpaceX's website as a base template and than modified it based on a lot of pre/during/post-flight pictures from the SpX COTS demo 2 mission.

title: Marble Trebuchet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a rough 1/8 scale model of my teams entry into Punkin Chunkin ( http://www.punkinchunkin.com/ ). There is a good deal of tuning which goes into a trebuchet and it's difficult to work it all out full scale since we only get some many shots between repairs. This model is to facilitate tuning work. Also just for fun. We enter purely for fun and our budget it way on the low side to be competitive but that's no excuse not to tune up. At full scale the treb is 12 feet tall to the pivot and uses 1000lbs (1400 with add-ons) counterweight to throw 8 lbs pumpkins. Simulations show a maximum range of a bit over 800 feet. Our best throws are only a bit over 400. At 1/8 scale it's about 18 in tall to the pivot, uses 2lbs counterweight and throws .25 ounce marbles. The first few days of throwing show a range of about 55 feet. The simulated max range is about 100 feet so there is tuning to do. Give enough time I would like to add a more efficient whipper style arm to the model/machine.

Print 2 of each part except the pivot. Cut the following lengths of 5/16 (8mm) rod:
6x20in
4x18in
2x9in
3x4in 1x34.5in (hardwood for this one if available) Other things you will need:
2x 608 bearings
1x5-6in 5/16 threaded rod
2-4 nuts for the threaded rod
eye screw with threads ground out for firing pin
finishing nail for sling release
String for rigging
pouch for sling
tent stakes to hold it down
2lbs of weight
.25 ounce projectiles (large marbles) Some rods fit in tightly for me and others I had to glue. In any case you will want to at least glue the diagonal supports into the base corners and the bearings into the holders as those will pull out as the weight swings. The pivot will slide on the hardwood rod and should also be secured. The pivot should be located 24in from one end of the arm. The sling length should be 21 in.

comments.text: Not sure if it's feasible for the scaled up design, or if your competition allows it, but the addition of wheels may also help increase its range- http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/lostempires/trebuchet/wheels.htmlwww.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/lostempi...
comments.author: ShipwreckedMonkey

comments.text:
It's been considered before but the
wheeled configuration is primarily for a fixed weight trebuchet.
When the weight can swing anyway you don't see much of an
improvement.
comments.author: ShipwreckedMonkey

title: Team Fortress 2 TF2 Dispenser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a dispenser from the popular online free to play game - TF2.  
I may be adding some tools and ammo to go in  the draw at the bottom as in the game.  
In the downloads there are the STL parts, the sketchup source file and a pre-made zip of all of the STLs.  
Enjoy erectin' your dispensarrs!  
NOTICE: The original concept for this model, the Team Fortress 2 - Dispenser, is copyright of Valve Software Incorporated 2012.

I have not yet tested the model and might not get to it this year even. I can see that "Gas Bottle Pipe" and "Gas Clip" will need supports, the gas clip less so.  
There is a gap of about 0.3mm between parts that need to slot into each other. I think that will be an adequate amount for mine, maybe a little too much for other printers.  
Please use the dispenser.skp for assembly. It has the model with all parts both laid out and assembled.  
Happy building!

description.header: This is an extension for our Faberdashery Spool (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:312471)
description.text:
Reading this :
http://www.fabbaloo.com/blog/2014/5/11/making-long-duration-3d-prints-more-reliable?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter Confirmed my experience on long prints. If you want flawless long prints, you'll need really smooth filament supply. This axe is perfect for long prints with Faberdashery coils.

• 2 outside walls
  • 30% infill
  • 39g of filament

• Print the file
  • clip 2 x 608 bearings (dont hesitate to put a bit of pressure). it will fit tightly. use some sand-paper if your printer is not precise enough.
  • try to use ABEC 5 bearings or higher to have the best fluidity.
  • glue the axe part to the spool. Let it dry.
  • use 8mm bars
  • you can use our Spool Stand V4 to support the 8mm bars (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:320376).
    • We wish you long long long... nice prints ;)

description.text: This bracket holds an emergency stop button with a 20mm mounting hole. The flanges are sized to match the 20mm Mitsumi extrusions used on the MendelMax

Slide your emergency stop button/switch through the mounting hole and tighten. Use two 4mm screws to mount it to the extrusion.
I have wired mine into the 12V line leading to my RAMPS board. If anything goes wrong just hit the button and all the motors and heaters shut down immediately.

comments.text:
Hi
You say you wired yours in series with your main 12V supply... did you check the maximal current of the switch ?
comments.author: uski

comments.text: Just to be safe, it might be a good idea to move the switch to the AC side of the circuit. I am using an 8 amp supply so it would definitely fall within the rated range of the switch. It is up to each person to check the ratings of their equipment before they make any additions or modifications.
comments.author: uski

comments.text: Thanks for the heads up. According to the spec sheet this switch is rated for 1200 watts. I am running 12 volts at 15 amps for a total of 180 watts so I am well below the rated power.
comments.author: uski

comments.text:
The problem is not the watts, it's the amps :)
A 600V 10A switch may be able to handle 6000W at 600V, but only 120W at 12V.
comments.author: BradDudenhoffer

comments.text: It would probably be best to use the e-stop switch to trigger a relay. 12V 30A automotive relays are less the US$15.
comments.author: uski

comments.text: Yes.

remixed_from.author: iksbob
remixed_from.title: Bracket For RAMPS On Kossel Mini

description.text: A simple RAMPS1.4 holder for mounting the electronics below a Kossel Mini printbed. Suitable for Kossels with 15x15 extrusions. Note: The bed has to be raised slightly by about 1cm, to have enough clearance for the large thermal fuses.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer thickness

• Slice model and print mount. I used Slic3r with 0.2mm layer thickness and a 0.5mm J-Head nozzle.
  • Place printed mount inside of your Kossel Mini base. The triangle shaped cutout will allow enough clearance around the stepper motor.
  • Use 4x M3x10mm screws, washers and nuts to mount holder in the base of your Kossel Mini. Do not tighten nuts, yet.
  • Insert RAMPS and check for enough clearance on all sides, especially around the USB port. You might want to check with a USB cable installed.
  • Remove electronics and tighten screws.
  • Insert RAMPS again and mount it with M3 screws. The screws will cut itself into the plastic.
  • Connect controller board with cables.
  • Install your print bed.
  • Have fun with your cleaned up Kossel Mini. ;-)
    Note: The bed has to be raised slightly by about 1cm, to have enough clearance for the large thermal fuses.

Parts used (BOM):
  • 1x RAMPS1.4 mount (printed)
  • 4x M3x10mm allen head screws (estimated, length has to be verified)
  • 4x M3 allen head screws for mounting RAMPS board
  • 4x M3 washers
  • 4x M3 nuts

author: jaeil

description.text: This is a hold for a rock wall system that uses standard bolts

I have not fully tested it but when printing use at least 4-5 shells, I am testing different % of object fill and will update when I find a good mix.
!!!!WARNING!!!!
Climbing can be dangerous. All climbing hold that are tested on your own, is your responsibility and should be tested in a safe and controlled environment. I just finished testing on the holds and it will depending on the use of the holds, here are the minimum requirements;
For just a hand hold: 4 Shells with a 20% object fill, but if the hole on the wall is bigger I would suggest 5 shells.
For Hand and foot hold: 5 Shells with 35-40% object, also if the wall has a bigger hole I would put 7 shells.
Remember these are just the min requirements! The biggest problem that I had was when i would tighten the bolt to the wall and the wall hole was big enough to fit the bolt and 4 shells so with the lower object fill it would pull the inner shells out of the hold.

title: Filament Spool Holder with 25mm Carbon Tube

description.text: I like to have some filament spools available. So i can change quickly from ABS to PLA and from one to colour to another. At the wall I have a Ikea shelf (LACK http://www.ikea.com/es/es/catalog/products/50193732/) and under them is where the hooks are installed with 2 screws each one. The carbon tube is from Hobbyking. Its 500 mm x 25 mm and very cheap, about 7$ (http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__7664__Carbon_Fiber_Round_Tube_500x25x23mm.html). You can install the 2 caps optionally. Theres a M3 hole for another screw or you can glue them. I glued. Tha caps are because the carbon fiber tube can go slowly to one of the sides, so with the caps it doesn't fall down. The symbol at the cap is my version of the Stargate Earth Symbol (http://www.worldstopbrands.com/brand/stargate-earth-symbol) I printed with ABS, 0.15 layer height and 30% infill. Hope you like.

author: reidc

title: Light Shaft for Panasonic Lumix DMC-TZ Camera

description.text:
The friend who took some videos of my driving boats could sometimes hardly see anything on the display. That is the reason why I decided to design a light shaft.
I found out that the first rectangular part, as you can also buy it foldable, is not sufficient enough.
Therefore, I added a pyramidal part, which is simply to slip onto the first part.
In this combination it is noticeable better, though it is recommended to be as close as possible.
The frame is glued to the box and everything is easy to secure with a rubber band that is hooked into the small hooks.
I tested it with the Panasonic Lumix DMC TZ7 and TZ22 and I think it may also fit for a lot others of this type.
The best of course, would be a closed housing with an adjustable magnifying glass, but I haven't found such a glass. I will be glad if you tell me your opinion and suggestions for improvements are welcome.

My print settings frame: layer height = 0.2 mm, width = 0.3 mm, infill = 0.2
shaft: layer height = 0.3 mm, width = 0.5 mm, infill = 0.3

comments.text: It's not a bug. When you set shaft diameter to 10mm with the default base diameter (20mm), there is no space left for the screws, so it disappears automatically. To increase shaft diameter more than 9mm but keep screw holes, you need to increase base diameter also. Please watch the pulley with the bottom view when you customise it, this will help you.

description.text:
This watch-band is designed to snap-together so you can print different colors and swap out links on the fly. This is still a work in progress, the clasp needs a lot of work, and the links need to be beefed up. Nonetheless, I have no trouble wearing it for about a month before having any issues!
Designed for the Fossil watch as pictured.

Print at 30% infill:
Each Watch should include:
2x watch_link_end.stl
1x watch_link_clasp_2.stl
1x watch_link_clasp_1.stl
1x watch_clasp_clip.stl
8x watch_link2.stl
To Snap together/apart, get two of the links at a 90 degree angle to each-other, and add a little torsion. You'll notice that the rectangular male 'peg' will match the female side with the notch.

8x 16mm rods
8x linear bearing 16mm SCS16UU
4x NEMA 17 Stepper
4x bearings (todo)
4x threaded rod
1x heating wire
.x Some screws CNC Controler Board What is still missing:
  • the bearings for the threaded rods
  • the top part to hold the vertical axis and rods

Other 3D bone models will soon follow this one.

comments.text:
Hi I found the Problem:
In your code is a mistake
void loop(){
dist = sonar.convert_cm( sonar.ping_median(5) );
//Serial.println(dist);
time = millis();
if( dist > 10 && (time - strafe_time > STRAFE_TIMEOUT) ){
strafe_right_flag = 0;
strafe_left_flag = 0;
forward();
} else {
if( !strafe_right_flag ){
strafe_right_setup();
strafe_right_flag = 1;
strafe_time = millis();
} else
forward(); // Original it was strafe_right then it only walks right!
}
comments.author: norf

comments.text: There are no errors in the code! The robot moves forward only if the distance > 10cm (as metioned in 'if' operator). I think your problem in the measurement of the distance. Uncomment "Serial.begin(9600);" and "Serial.println(dist);". Check the values of the "dist" variable in the COM-Monitor.

This is modified to move the drive gear 0.6mm further away from the filament path than the original.  
This should allow a much straighter filament path, similar to 1.75mm setup. The original caused the filament to bow around the drive gear.  
The best solution would be to make the mounting bolts slots, so that the distance can be changed for the hot-end in use.  
UPDATE: I've added a hole for a 3mm allen key, for easier large gear removal, and increased the depth of the inlet on the top piece.
Print, drill/clean, fit as normal.

I've designed this top plate conveyor for a project I'm working on. I chose this conveyor because it is very flexible in terms of being able to go around corners and also because it should be very quiet. (The idea being to use it in a board room setting - more on this later).
This design requires 3 608 bearings for each plate. I am still finalising the drive mechanism and will update when complete, but the idea is to use a spring as a flexible worm drive and shown in the image.
The conveyor would also require a track depending on your specific implementation which is not shown in the gallery.
An M6 nut holds the plate onto the central bearing while 2 M3 nuts will connect each plate with its connector.
More info on this project at: https://sites.google.com/site/gineer/cremabot Gineer R&D

title: Telescope or Microscope Adapter for iPhone 5

description.text:
The original design was close, but was a bit short for an iPhone 5. It still worked, but was not optimal. I lengthened the model to make it fit and separated the eyepiece to it's own stl file. I also modified the eyepiece to fit the microscopes we have at our school. Original File:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39308

My models were created in Tinkercad. Printed in PLA works perfect. When printed in ABS it is very difficult to insert the tabs from the eyepiece into the holes on the main body. To take pictures you need to lock the auto focus and for best results use the digital zoom to remove the vignetting. My Tinkercad Models:
https://tinkercad.com/things/3CpgC90q2to-modified-telescope-mount-for-iphone-5-lamee-labs https://tinkercad.com/things/fkgAeBtuA1U-telescope-eyepiece-for-iphone-5-lamee-labs https://tinkercad.com/things/7el7RbjE1jJ-microscope-eyepiece-for-iphone-5-lamee-labs

Koch snowflakes are created by successively extending the sides of a triangle. I found a very nice description of the Koch method and a fortran program that was used to calculate all the examples given below at: http://hmf.enseeiht.fr/travaux/CD9900/travaux/optmfn/hi/00pa/mfn16/part2.html Enseeiht is a French engineering school in Tolouse and the author of the article is Alain Schuler. Koch Snowflake by gadgetguydk, (thing:1039), is a composite of three stages of Koch iteration of a triangle and Koch curve/snowflake by Cross, (thing:3166), is an embroidered version. Koch_composite_color_1.stl and Koch_composite_color_2.stl, available below, is a two color version of the same composite for the Replicator. Koch_three_snowflake.stl and Koch_four_snowflake.stl are monochrome examples of the Koch curve after 3 and 4 iterations of a triangle. The curves have been pierced with holes so that they can be hung as ornaments. The openSCAD programs that created the snowflakes are provided and they can be easily modified to create numerous variations.
Koch_three_snowflake.stl and Koch_four_snowflake.stl can be printed on a raft or directly on the build platform.

description.text: http://airtripper.com/1676/3d-printer-extruder-filament-drive-gear-review-benchmark/

The more improvements and new features added to the Sumpod 3d printer the more I want to use the 3d printer, and adding better filament handling has gone a long way to improve the 3d printer's ease of use.  
The Sumpod's sturdy construction has allowed me to set up a filament spool rack on the top of the printer.

A fast printing version of the bottle mustache.

I was asked to print out about 30 of these mustaches. The problem was that the original mustache took about 19 minutes to print and the clip was not as durable as I would have liked.  I googled 'mustache' and found the image that the original was based on and traced it in solidworks and added a glue on clip to speed up the print.  Now the mustache prints in less than 8 minutes and the clip just glues on with superglue (PLA) or acetone (ABS).
Enjoy.
These parts were made in SolidWorks and repaired in Netfabb to ensure they are perfectly manifold.

description.text: Inspired by the Wall Key Holder from Luiz Bello I made a design with a nice font on top of it.

Made in OpenScad. Copyright notice: Font created by svgFont2Scad by Bernhard -HotKey- Slawik, http://www.bernhardslawik.de
The font itself is called Designer Block by K-Type (http://www.k-type.com/?p=296). It's free for personal use but K-Type requires a paid license for commercial use.
Printed on a Prusa I3, 75% scaled. 3 mm filament ABS, 0,3 mm layerheight.

I was having some trouble getting the top section of Darthwahl's Floating Lighthouse Island (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23519/) to print. When I looked at the makerware slicer output, I saw gaps in the lighthouse/house. Evidently some of the surfaces didn't plot well in makerware. I imported the file into tinkercad, subtracted it from an arbitrary cubic volume, then subtracted that volume from another arbitrary cubic volume. The end result looks identical, but sliced well in makerware, with no floating lighthouse parts.

This bracket will mount a Mac Mini to the back of a monitor with 100mmx100mm mounting holes.

The Mac Mini should be a snug fit sliding in from the side.  
You may need to get longer screws for the monitor.  I used M4-.7 x 20mm Flat Head Philips Screws. Depending on your monitor you may need longer or shorter screws.

title: Replacement gear for Aurora AS424C shredder

description.text:
This is a replacement middle gear for the Aurora AS424C shredder, which tends to break due to excessive motor torque when the paper jams.
This gear is designed with pin holes of 1.1mm (adjustable in the SCAD file) in each of the smaller gear's teeth, so that you can stick metal pins into them for better shear strength without having to print it at an angle.
Update: Now with a hub for the top of the gear instead of pinholes to stabilize the top of the gear.

Print the gear flat, and stick rigid metal pins of 1.1mm diameter, and 15-18mm long into the pin holes for shear strength. Hammer the pins in as far as you can get them. Pins removed from thumbtacks work well for this purpose. Adjust the pin_diameter variable in shredder-gear.scad if you need pins of different sizes.

comments.text: I have a photo of my gear, but not sure how to upload here.
comments.author: JimmyDTD

comments.text: Click "I made one", and then fill in the form and upload the picture.
comments.author: JimmyDTD

comments.text: I did it, but don't see it.  Not sure if there is a moderator who has to approve it.  I'll look later.
comments.author: hyperair

comments.text: I see it. Whoops, I didn't realize you meant the original gear. I thought you meant that you had a printed gear you wanted to show.
comments.author: JimmyDTD

comments.text: I was looking for a replacement gear for my shredder when I came upon this post.  It's a nice looking part, but you are sorely mistaken if you think that you can replace a nylon or acetal gear with a 3D printed gear.  My guess is that this will last a few minutes and fall apart, if that long.  This type of application is stressed very severely, that's why the originals break.
comments.author: JimmyDTD

comments.text: Not just a few minutes. I've went through a few cycles of this already, which was why I ended up driving 1.1mm thumbtack pins into each tooth of the smaller gear. It seems to have lasted for a while now, but it definitely can't take the same amount of stress that the originals managed (rated for cutting one credit card, wow). It appears to work well enough if you feed paper in sheet by sheet, or four layers at a time, even.
comments.author: JimmyDTD

comments.text:
Well, that's good to run one sheet at a time. The pins may help a little.
As a side note, I contacted Aurora today, and they do not sell any replacement parts for their shredders. I'm usually pretty good at finding things, but I think that I will have to junk my shredder, which is a AS602MX. It has a plastic gear similar to yours with the center small gear being metal. That gear was totally worn out from contact with a larger metal gear before the plastic gear broke. So I'm going to look on Craigslist for another used one.
comments.author: hyperair

comments.text: Could you post pictures of how the gear train looks? If it's not a compound gear like this one, a printed gear can actually be pretty strong.

comments.text: OpenSCAD, with the standard involute_gear.scad library from the MCAD collection. I took a photograph of the top view of the original gear and overlayed it on top of the model using a translucent window, then tweaked the circular_pitch value until I got the gear size about the same dimensions as the original.

title: Hydron
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Hydron is a fully personalisable lamp, which projects imagery/text on the walls with light. You can alter it so that it shows or says something about you. Check out our blog to see our full design process http://opendesignflm.tumblr.com

• Download the blue print
  • Adjust the design to your own needs and wishes. Add your own patterns or words.
  • Test the lasercutter to find the correct setting needed for 2mm cardboard. It will be different for different lasercutters. We used power 100, Speed 3 and PPI/Hz 1000.
  • Cut out the net on the cardboard using the lasercutter
  • Save the letters - you can do something with those
  • Assemble the net (without glue) and fold all fold lines
  • Glue the net together - we found that wood glue worked well
  • When the net is dry, insert your choice of lighting.
  • Find a dark place so that you can experiment with the light.

My new YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnnw56J_TeOsF4M_F5pPPJQ This fully 3D printable ukulele (save for bolts and strings) uses an acoustic transducer to carry the lower frequency sound created by the strings to a very thin membrane on the bottom of the body. The sound is focused and projected out of channels in the body to (hopefully) create a fuller tone with reasonable amplitude. I am still working on the design of the head and tuners. Right now, to have a good gear ratio for the prototype, I made the gears almost comically large. UPDATE!!
I'm refining the design of the geared tuner head but I wanted to test the tonality to see if I was getting somewhere so I quickly designed a test friction head and tuning knobs to try it out. I have uploaded all the current parts for everyone to TEST this EXPERIMENTAL design! Have fun! VIDEO: http://youtu.be/4xRkysNNRc4 A couple of notes: I am tweaking the body design. The bridge is a little wonky and the transducer pops right off! I have to think that one over a bit. The bottom membrane is only two layers thin. It is tricky to print and even trickier to remove from the platform. BE SUPER-CAREFUL TO NOT TEAR THE MEMBRANE OFF! The sound the first prototype makes is bright as expected but it is pretty loud. A good sign! NOTE: This friction head is for testing only, it will no longer hold a tune after a while without shims or other "friction-enhancers." The geared tuner is the solution to this, I'm just working to make it a better, more reliable print. Stay tuned! If you like what I do and want to help me do more, please consider supporting me on my Patreon page! http://www.patreon.com/ErikJDurwoodII Thanks!
Print, bolt together, string, tune, and play!

A frame to fit a magnifying glass lens. The lens just snaps in to the one piece frame and handle. The handle is flattened top and bottom to facilitate printing while remaining symmetrical.  
The lens this was fit to measured 43.5mm in diameter with 1.6mm thickness at the edge. The frame is 6mm thick, a bit more then the lens's 4.5mm so that when resting the lens is not touching the surface.

remixed_from.title: Quick Change Spindle for 1lb filament spool

description.text: This device is used to transfer filament from the 1lb bundle to a 1kg spare reel. The flexMendel 3D Printer uses the frame as the Z slide and couldn't mount this to the side posts, plus using filament on a reel is much less troublesome. I got tired of transferring these by hand and thought to make a jig that would allow a cordless drill to spin the filament onto a spare reel. See video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C9vHzsMgx00 Thank you murat for the great project: "Quick Change Spindle for 1lb Filament Spool". http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13395

Materials:
A scrap 2x4 that is between 2'-4' long
5/16" threaded rod - I cut (2) 3" sections
(5/16" bolts will work but they should be at least 2" long)
5/16" nuts and washers - (6 each)

608zz bearings - (3 total) (8x22x7mm) Print out the reel holder created by murat here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13395 Print one of each part. Easy assembly of threaded rods and parts. See photos if not sure on positioning. Away you go...!

This part has been replaced by version 2.0: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3843 This is a parametric one-piece y-bar clamp. It replaces two y-bar clamp pieces from Mendel or Mini Mendel, and requires no screws! This is part of a larger project to overhaul the entire Mendel / Mini Mendel Huxley design to make the printable parts print faster and the non-printable parts easier to obtain.

The smooth rod goes through the flat side, and it is pinched by nuts on the threaded rod through the rounded side. Nylock nuts are recommended. The M8 version is for Mendle, and the M6 is for Mini Mendel Huxley.

title: Bride's Outfit for C. Rex
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: UPDATE: I added a wedding dress for the bride since my first edition. Recently, I published a groom's outfit (tux, top hat, and collar with bow tie, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:338599) for my Corkasaurus Rex, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:330220, using a new configuration for the rear legs that allows the corkasaur to stand upright on his hind feet. I also added a new top part for the C. Rex that brings the little "arms" together in front so that they can hold something - like a bridal bouquet! This thing is a trousseau for the corkasaurus bride. Included are a ribboned bouquet and veil. The veil shown in the photos is based on chainmail developed by The3DLibrary - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30686 - and can easily (but carefully) be shaped by hand to drape around the bride's "shoulders." Because this print is rather time consuming, I also included two earlier versions of the veil that print quicker, are flat and must be heated (like with a hair dryer for PLA) to be shaped. I include just the pillbox hat for those who wish to go multimedia and add a circle of fabric to it for a veil.

The wedding dress worked well with 0.3 mm layers and 3 shells, sliced in Cura and printed in PLA.  
All the other things shown in the photos were all sliced with 0.2 mm layers and 2 shells/perimeters. No extra support or any rafts were used (although The3DLibrary suggests a raft - which I did not use).  
The flat veils were sliced in Slic3r using one perimeter, 0.2 mm layers and hexagonal infill (to create a lacy look). The large flat veil probably looks better warmed and shaped to a more cylindrical form, the small one is really OK as is (sporty!)  
I printed the stems for the bouquet in green PLA and the top (blossoms) in white, then painted the centers of the blossoms yellow and background in green acrylic. I think it would look OK if the entire top were printed in a single color instead. Glue the blossoms (top) to the stems. The ribbon nestles between her "arms" with a tube part that holds the stems of the bouquet. Museum wax, poster mounting putty (or chewing gum - yuk!) may be needed to keep the pillbox hat and ribbon in place.

title: Flexible coupling ~ 5mm stepper to 3/8" lead screw

description.text:
IMPORTANT
You must turn down the stepper current for your z axis motor before using this coupling (if you print it in pla). On the standard one/two-up, the stepper currents are set too high by default and as a result, the steppers get very hot. This can actually allow the coupler to deform enough to become unusable, so be sure you turn down the current! Here is a flexible coupling I designed for my two-up 3d printer. It's design allows it to be printed relatively quickly, it has support for up to 3 set screws (although only 1 is absolutely necessary) and it has plastic spiral pieces in the center to allow for the screw to pivot if it is not perfectly centered. Requires at least 1 M3 nut and 1 M3x8mm or longer bolt . Notice that if your z-stepper gets hot during use, you may be required to use all 3 bolts. If you have just one and it gets too hot, it could force the coupler to permanently deform. Using 3 screws will prevent that problem. Fully compatible with the one/two up with the stock gantry or with stefanburgers 3d printed gantry.

This is a butter dish.
It's minimalistic design was made to be easy to manufacture, and the most simply possible keep the butter and the lid in place with the two bumps. Whereas the space under the base is made, not just for the style, but to take and hold the whole. Initially it was intended for the local pottery course. But before we build it with clay, I made a prototype (on a dimension3D)... so maybe it will interest people who have a 3Dprinter (even more if you can print ceramic) :) You can see more pictures here : http://www.behance.net/gallery/Beurrier--Butter-dish/557219
And the making-of, where we can see the printed and the clay model here : http://watsdesign.blogspot.com/2010/06/beurrier-open-source.html
Just print the two part (base & couvercle) and that's it ! Bon appÃ©tit ;)
The original dust skirt on our ShopBot  took one too many hits. I designed this using partworks but I'll include the DXF file for you to take this to any cad/cam combo.

I used some scrap pieces of 3/8" polycarbonate cut to 5"x12". This required me to come up with a custom holddown solution to do the cutting. I used a jig cut from MDF and a good amount of double stick tape. You could skip the jig if you cut these parts from a full sheet.
First I routed a 1/4" inch deep pocket into the MDF. This held the material in place as I made my cuts.
Next I cut the main shoe. It's the part that clamps onto the spindle. the small hole clamps on using a split in the shoe and a 2" #8 bolt. The large hole accepts a standard 4" dust collection hose connector.
Then I cut 3 identical skirt/spacer parts. One of them gets the vinyl skirt material attached to it. The other 2 are used as spacers when using longer bits.
The design has 4 1/4" holes used to hold some 3/8" x 1/4" magnets. These are what hold all of the layers together.

comments.text: I made one of these and it came out nicely (but haven't printed with it yet).  One possible gotcha is that imitation j-heads can have larger aluminum blocks at the bottom (near hotend exit) that stick out more in all directions, to where there's an interference with the hotend corners and the thin inner edge of the fan shroud.  The hole for the heater/resistor is noticeably closer to the hotend center on a real j-head, so this interference doesn't occur there.

This is a grenade inspired by the Grenade container (the threading is similar but I don't think they are interchangeable) and the modern Swedish hand grenades SHGR90 and SHGR2000 hence I call it SHGR95. Apart from the design of the grenade body the big difference is that my handle can fly off completely. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQEuGaKdda4 The sprint and pin are made from 1.5mm stainless steel wire.

I have an old Garmin eTrex hand held GPS.  I must have got it 10 years ago at least.  It's very simple and good for keeping track of distance hiked or biked.  Unfortunately I lost the handlebar mount some where in the mists of time.  This is a replacement.
I tried a couple of designs.  It was hard to get the overhanging tabs to work so that the GPS device would snap into place.  I used a fillet on the underside so that the overhanging pieces could be built out layer by layer.  That seemed to work.

The instructions are pretty simple.  Print the bracket and the handlebar clamp.  Bolt them together.  
The clamp may not fit your handlebars.  It is sized for a 25mm diameter tube.  You can edit the source file if you need a different size clamp.  The clamp will flex quite far to snap over the handlebars, but if the bars are too big then you can't get a bolt through the holes. If the bar is too small then you can pad it.  Bike lights come with strips of rubber for that purpose.
The holes are sized for 3mm bolts.  You need a 10mm bolt to hold the two pieces together and a 20mm bolt for the clamp.  You may need to clear the holes out a little with a drill bit.  They were tight on the print that I made.

comments.text: Did you try to print this vertically? It may get rid of your overhang problem. I'd give it a shot, but I have a newer eTrex that uses a different mount.

comments.text: I have a MendelMax.  I had a little trouble with my "V2 Wades" and J-Head.  I'm also using a X cartridge that has mounts on both the front and back.  This way I use the adjustable belt tensioner and have another mount for the fan.  In my configuration it is very tight.  I had to sand the mount so that it was lower.  I also made the screw hole on the mount a little lower by using a drill bit as a saw.  Once I did this the duct was level (Just below the smooth rod).  The hotend is just below the duct (2mm).  Very tight fit.  I also had to do some surgery on the Wades (I cut a corner off the bottom), because it rubbed up against the belt tensioner.  Oh and I had to cut the duct bracket as well.  My wades is also at a 45% angle.  All in all a very tight fit.  But I got it all to work.  I have found that a fan is a must.  On my Prusa Mendel I have a fan, but it does not go around the print head, it just cools from the back.  The back prints perfect, but the front still has problems.  I believe that this duct will work miracles!

description.text: NAME: Jedel Parghoga SPECIES: Zyntradi ORIGIN: Zyntradi Commonwealth A renowned sharpshooter and notorious psychopath, Jedelâ€™s guns are for hire to anyone with enough credits and moral lenience to meet their price. Little is known of Jedelâ€™s past, though one can often tell where Jedel has been based on the â€œsplatter artâ€ left behind. Jedel considers itself a true artist, canvassing the walls with the its opponentsâ€™ ichors. Model designed in Sculptris and TinkerCAD, 3d printed on a Makerbot Replicator and hand-painted with water-based acrylics. https://tinkercad.com/things/l7TqwcQCgpF-jedel-parghoga-zyntradi-gunslinger-30characterschallenge This is my twelfth entry for the 30 Characters Challenge. Each day in November I'll be designing and posting a new model (though the prints may come a tad later, depending on how on-the-ball I am). Each character is randomly generated using the Continuum Narrative Engine (a storytelling game system currently in the works here at the Ill Gotten Games headquarters). I'll get the rest posted here as I print them, but for now you can follow the WIP models here... 30characters.com/author/dutch-mogul/

Printed with a 10% infill at a .10 layer height, extruder temp at 230. After he was assembled, he was painted with water-based acrylics. He was printed raftless on a .10mm "raft" to give support during printing and, more importantly, allowing all of the pieces to be taken off the electrician;s tape a little easier.

Designed as an Electronics or Engineering project for a Senior High School student, this combines 3D printing, circuit board manufacture, surface mount soldering and optional Bluetooth communications to create a simple and solid mini-sumo robot.  
The circuit board files are for DesignSpark PCB. The Bluetooth Test code will work with the Android App "BlueBots". It can also be programmed to use a TV infra-red remote control or run autonomously.  
This project does work... I've supervised the construction of a couple dozen so far. You may need to create a mold for casting the urethane tires to get a perfect fitting tire.  
Further documentation is included in the attached files. The "BCIT TTED" imprint on the back of the robot refers to the British Columbia Institue of Technology's "Technology Teacher Education" program. We have been preparing technology (aka "shop") teachers to teach metalwork, woodwork, drafting, mechanics and electronics to high school students for the past fifty years. I wonder if our grads from the '60's ever saw this coming!

Worm gears find many uses in engineering applications due to their compact size and high gear reduction ratios. A disadvantage of this type of gear set is that only one tooth on the spur gear is engaged (or "in mesh") with the worm gear at any time. This causes high contact stresses which can accelerate wear. This thing is a demonstration model of a hyperbolic (also known as an enveloping) worm gear. Both the worm gear and the spur gear teeth are cut from hyperbolic surfaces. This allows multiple teeth on the spur gear to engage the worm simultaneously. This reduces the contact stress between the gears, and allows higher torques to be transmitted through the gearset. A video showing the motion of the hyperbolic worm gears is shown here: http://youtu.be/O-MFFjBNCb8. In this design 12 teeth on the spur are theoretically in constant mesh with the worm gear, although manufacturing tolerances result in less-than-perfect contact. The gear reduction is 72:1 (72 revolutions of the worm gear produce one revolution of the spur gear). Both the worm and spur are constructed using true involute gear tooth profiles. The worm gear is horizontally mounted on a pair of knife-edge bearings, and the spur is fastened to a vertical shaft using a c-clip. This model makes an excellent hands-on demonstration of worm gears for a wide range of students. It can also be used as a challenge: computing and modeling the worm gear geometry is non-obvious. The solidworks files for the worm and spur have been attached for anyone interested.

Print one copy of all parts except bearing_cap; you'll need two of those. All parts should be printed in the default orientation with no support. A layer thickness of 0.2 mm is best for the involute and spur gears; the layer thicknesses on the other parts is not critical.   
Four M3 (or similar) screws are needed to affix the bearing caps to the base.  
The worm gear requires a bit of cleanup - a large pad is included to improve print bed attachment which should be trimmed off. Some of the gear teeth are printed with very steep overhangs, a little work with a sharp razor will be needed to get smooth gear rotation.   
A 10mm socket or drill driver can be used to spin the gearset more rapidly. It is advisable to lubricate the knife-edge bearings holding the worm gear with graphite to avoid excessive friction.

comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
"... 12 teeth on the spur are in constant mesh with the worm gear..."
Are you sure all 12 teeth are making contact?
I was reading about drilling and tapping holes in metal. One crusty old machinist said something I'd never thought about.. something like "Regarding strength, a nut (or a hole) doesn't actually use more than 2 or 3 threads since regardless how many, only 2 or 3 make contact with the bolt's thread."
I suspect it's the same situation with gears, sliding mechanisms, and similar. One or a few points of contact carry the whole load at any particular moment in time.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
Ah yes, this is a good question. In the mathematically perfect world of CAD, all the teeth are in harmonious simultaneous mesh. However, as you point out, due to manufacturing tolerances (not to mention the effects of layered manufacturing) only a few points are in actual physical contact. Here is where the argument made by the old machinist breaks down: Local deformation occurs at the highly-stressed initial contact points when torque is applied to the worm. This serves to redistribute the stress more widely across contact patches on the same, and on other, gear teeth. Even with this redistribution, the contact is not as complete and uniform as the CAD model would naively imply.
Basically, the argument made by the crusty old machinist neglects the elastic and plastic deformations present in bolted joints. I've actually worked with fasteners in critical applications where we torqued bolts beyond the point of permanent plastic deformation in order to ensure full-length thread engagement.
Regardless, the point about the importance of manufacturing tolerances is a good one, and I've edited my description a bit to make this more clear.
Cheers!
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
Deformation wasn't exactly neglected. In fact it is the reason only 2 or 3 threads (at the end of the bolt) make contact. The rest move away from contact with the bolt's thread as the bolt stretches under normal torque.
A bolt might be torqued so high as to stretch it even further to get more threads in "contact", but those new contacts would be on the opposing surfaces of the threads. I don't see where that exercise provides any mechanical advantage, not to mention the bolt being much closer to its breaking point.
This gear "neglects" a few things as well. For instance, (assuming it is perfectly formed) there's roughly 12X the friction losses a conventional worm suffers, and it certainly ignores the cost and difficulty of manufacture as compared to a properly sized standard gear.
.. but I really hate to cap on this design... it's beautiful. You know your stuff. I'm jealous..
comments.author: jsteuben

comments.text: Would there be 12x the frictional losses? If I remember my schooling friction force is proportional to normal force. So, if the load is distributed across more than one tooth up to the theoretical 12 teeth, I would think the friction per tooth would ultimately reduced.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
Since the load is distributed among the teeth, it makes sense the

comments.author: odie_wan

comments.text:
Would there be 12x friction losses? Intuitively, I would think that the friction torque would be roughly equivalent, maybe even worse in the spur gear design...I happen to be working on a steering box now and was wondering if there was any advantage to cut the sector/rack gears for a hyperbolic mesh.
Anyway, great model jsteuben!
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
I wasn't speaking of torque. Shaft bearings take care of that. I was thinking tooth contact. Friction causes wear, and gears wear at the teeth because that's where the friction is. All 12 teeth in contact would seem to mean some amount of increased friction.
If the objective is to transmit more power without using bigger gears, then more teeth in contact will distribute the load. If there is more friction it is an acceptable price to pay.
If bolt/nut thread force distribution and gearing are related, and if 33% of a load is carried by one tooth while virtually 100% is carried by 6 teeth, then perhaps a 6 tooth spur is enough. It won't look quite as pretty but should get the job done.

description.text: Kolo33's AT-AT model has some nice design detail but is hard to print, and the pose is somewhat arbitrary. This is an improved version. I fixed problems related to too-thin geometry, strange internal faces, areas that didn't join properly and so on. I also divided the model into parts based on the natural joints and added allowances so they can rotate. This allows the model to be posed, although the final pose will need to be glued to be able to hold its own weight. Completed model stands 30 cm high. Based on: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:215574

• head, gun_L, gun_R: glue guns into holes
  • body_front, body_mid, body_back: glue together, attach head
    some alternate orientations are provided
  • chassis_front, chassis_rear: glue to base of body
  • chassis_plug x4, leg_upper x4: glue plug into chassis so leg can rotate
    these are mirror-symmetric

  • leg_mid x4: slip on upper leg joint

  • for the bottom leg you have two options:
    -- legA_L, legA_R: left and right versions of the bottom leg segment and foot, with the foot centered
    -- legB_main, legB_foot, legB_insert, legB_strut, legB_strut_peg: glue insert into main allowing foot to rotate. Once foot is posed glue strut and peg into place. A short piece of filament instead of the strut peg works great

  • pose entire assembly, glue all joints into place

comments.text: Hi, nice model, i finished print and now im gluing it, I found no difference between legA_L and legA_R, is just me?
comments.author: fishbone99

comments.text: Yes, the part is symmetric so mirroring has no effect.
comments.author: fishbone99

comments.text: Hey mate, amazing model! Almost finished printing all the parts now. Some parts were quite annoying to print though, needing a lot of support material. I feel like you could have separated some parts to make it a lot easier to print, especially the head and neck. Anyways, it seamed to all work out in the end. What tolerance did you use for the chassis parts to connect to the underpart of the body, or the tolerance for the leg pieces. These tolerances worked really well on my printer, that's why I'm curious.
comments.author: mohawkpod

comments.text: Glad you like it! Yes, it can be a challenging print. Tolerances were 200-400 micons.
comments.author: mohawkpod

comments.text: I am still new to 3D printing and having some struggles getting parts of this model to print correctly.I got the body back, chassis front and rear and chassis plugs to print without issue. The guns that mount to the head have some issues on the little part that protrudes under the gun barrel, but I can retry them or just live with it. The head didn't turn out so well. It seemed to me that printing it standing up on the neck would be the best way. But there was so much support material around the neck to hold up the head it was impossible to remove it all cleanly. And support material also got into the vent ports on the lower back side of the head. I've not had a lot of luck with printing using supports so far with several models. I'm going to read up on it more. I've heard I can change the support type/grid to make them easier to remove. Using an original prusa i3 mk2. Is it best to print the head just as it comes in the STL? I assume this will require a lot of support material on the underside of the entire head, correct? But that still may be easier to remove then from around the neck.
comments.author: mikef208

comments.text: The guns are a pain to print because they're so narrow. You could try printing both left and right at the same time. For me that sometimes slows down the print enough that the filament can cool before more is deposited.
comments.author: mikef208
